Topic.Title: California State Teacher's Retirement fund owns 6.67% of the Company owning Bushmaster .223

Message.Msg: "The California State Teachers' Retirement System (CalSTRS) committed to invest a whopping $500 million into a $7.5 billion Cerberus fund that has helped bankroll Freedom Group. That means that it effectively could own a 6.67% stake in the gun maker, which filed to go public in late 2009 before pulling the offering in early 2011. In fact, the figure could be even higher since CalSTRS also committed $100 million to a $1.4 billion predecessor fund, which likely made the original investment." Maybe? Possibly due to investment into a predecessor fund? "On Tuesday, private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management announced that in response to the shootings at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., it intends to divest itself from its ownership of gunmaker Freedom Group." Very past tense.

Message.Title: Microsoft ups Surface production to sell in more stores and match demand
Message.Msg: GOOGLE IT Microsoft ups Surface production, to sell in more stores ReutersReuters – Tue, Dec 11, 2012 5:22 PM EST... Related Content. . .Sales staff demonstrate the Microsoft Surface during the opening of Microsoft's retail store in New York's Times Square October 25, 2012. REUTERS/Keith BedfordView Photo. Sales staff demonstrate the Microsoft Surface during the opening of Microsoft's retail store in New York's Times Square October 25, 2012. REUTERS/Keith Bedford ARM.L 775.00 18.00 . SEATTLE (Reuters) - Microsoft Corp has stepped up manufacturing of the Surface tablet, its new device designed to counter Apple Inc's iPad, and will introduce it to third-party retailers this week. The moves suggest Microsoft is seeing some demand for its first own-brand computer in the crucial holiday shopping season, although it has yet to divulge any sales figures. "The public reaction to Surface has been exciting to see," said Panos Panay, general manager of Microsoft's Surface project, which forms part of the company's Windows unit. "We've increased production and are expanding the ways in which customers can interact with, experience and purchase Surface," said Panay, but gave no details of how many extra units were being produced. Panay did not mention names of retailers that will sell the Surface, but separately office equipment retailer Staples Inc said it would stock the tablet from Wednesday. He said the Surface would also be on sale at retailers in Australia from mid-December, with more countries to follow in the next few months. Since launch in late October, the Surface has only been sold by Microsoft itself, in its own brick and mortar stores in the United States and Canada and online in Australia, China, France, the UK and Germany. The only Surface model available now - officially called Surface with Windows RT - runs a version of Windows created to work on the low-power chips designed by ARM Holdings, which dominate smartphones and tablets but are incompatible with old Windows applications. It starts at $499 for the 32 gigabyte version plus $120 for a thin cover that doubles as a keyboard. A larger, heavier tablet - called Surface with Windows 8 Pro - will be introduced in January, running on an Intel Corp chip that works with all Microsoft's Windows and Office applications. Microsoft plans to price the new Surface from $899 for a 64 gigabyte version. The world's largest software company also said it would keep its chain of 'pop-up' holiday stores open into the new year and will convert them into permanent retail outlets or what it called "specialty store locations". Microsoft's recent push into physical retail - following Apple's great success - has resulted in 31 permanent stores plus 34 holiday ‘pop-up' stores in the U.S. and Canada. If Microsoft converted each of the temporary stores into permanent outlets it would have 65 stores, still well below Apple with almost 400 worldwide. (Reporting by Bill Rigby in Seattle, Sruthi Ramakrishnan in Bangalore)

Message.Title: American Gun Deaths to Exceed Traffic Fatalities by 2015
Message.Msg: Bloomberg By Chris Christoff & Ilan Kolet - Dec 18, 2012 9:00 PM CT While motor vehicle deaths dropped 22 percent from 2005 to 2010, gun fatalities are rising again after a low point in 2000, according to the Atlanta-based Centers for Disease Control. Shooting deaths in 2015 will probably rise to almost 33,000, and those related to autos will decline to about 32,000, based on the 10-year average trend. As the nation reels from the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School, the shift shows the effects of public policy, said Garen Wintemute, director of the Violence Prevention Research Program at the University of California, Davis. The fall in traffic deaths resulted from safer vehicles, restricted privileges for young drivers and seat-belt and other laws, he said. By contrast, “we’ve made policy decisions that have had the impact of making the widest array of firearms available to the widest array of people under the widest array of conditions.” While fewer households have guns, people who own guns are buying more of them, he said. ********************************************************************************************* The number of right wing nut jobs is declining but they are getting whackier.

Topic.Title: Microsoft ups Surface production to sell in more stores and match demand

Message.Msg: Lenovo has three different convertible form factors, the Twist, the Yoga, and the X Series. The Yoga actually resembles the Surface but is a convertible. The Surface, as compared to a convertible, has to be assembled on a table top. Now Samsung has a 13.3" Series 9 laptop at 2.6 pounds weight. And the convertible tablets are too heavy at about 3.5 pounds weight. So the obvious thing to do is a Samsung 11.6" Series 9 convertible. The problem is that journalists and analysts have declared the price point to be $500. Well, isn't a really good computer more like $1000 ? And isn't the acceptance of a $500 price point an admission that ARM tablets are just coffee-shop browsers ? Now Samsung has a detachable tablet. The ATIV 500T is about $750 including optional keyboard and the ATIV 700T is about $1200 includng optional keyboard. Both will run Photoshop but the 500T is for longer battery life while the 700T is for higher performance. Then HP has an Elite Pad 900 tablet scheduled for January while Lenovo has a Thinkpad 2 tablet not yet available.

Message.Title: 100 Best Companies to Work For
Message.Msg: Microsoft ranks number 76, three steps below Starbucks, and three steps above Mattel. It's down four steps from last year. Google? It's number one.

Message.Title: 50 most admired companies
Message.Msg: Microsoft does better this time, it's number 17. Its neighbors are General Electric, American Express, 3M and Caterpillar -- all solid, if unexciting, companie. The top three are Apple, Google and Amazon, in that order.

Topic.Title: 35 in 9 months

Message.Msg: Microsoft should offer Windows 9 XP. Use the back end of Windows 8, but with an XP look-alike graphical interface. They'd sell millions of copies and maybe get XP users to upgrade. Just make sure it runs on XP hardware and supports older printer and scanner drivers. Meanwhile, over 20% of users are still running XP and NOT Windows 8!

Message.Title: Surface abysmal sales
Message.Msg: "The latest move is one again around that unloved child of Redmond that has seen abysmal sales. No not Windows 8, the other unloved child of Redmond, the Surface tablet. You might recall the highs and lows of Surface, and the soap opera it has become. This week, Microsoft has admitted their strategy is broken, Surface is failing, and so they backpedalled hard. Unfortunately, it was right over the feet of all the hardware partners that they had run over earlier, the ones they barely kept from outright rebellion a few months ago."

Message.Title: MSFT Surface DOA
Message.Msg: "And so Surface failed, and Microsoft reacted, and broke their promises to the entire OEM base. Now you can buy a Surface at Best Buy, others will soon follow. That sub-1% non-Surface tablet sales number may be the high water mark. See Microsoft. See Microsoft panic. See Microsoft have no clue. See Microsoft management flail. See Microsoft react. See Microsoft kick the other leg out from under their OEM partners. See problem? Microsoft sure doesn’t."

Topic.Title: Microsoft ups Surface production to sell in more stores and match demand

Message.Msg: So why did cut the production from 4 million by half over a month ago?

Message.Title: "Surface couldn’t meet half of expected demand in spite of Windows 8, Christmas, and fanboi fervor. It is DOA."

Topic.Title: Surface abysmal sales

Message.Msg: Lenovo has three convertible form factors, the Twist, the Yoga, and the X Series. The Yoga actually resembles the Surface but is a convertible. The Surface, compared to a convertible, has to be assembled on a table-top for keyboard use. The problem with the convertibles is that they weigh about 3.5 pounds. Now Samsung has a 13.3" Series 9 laptop that weighs about 2.6 pounds. So the obvious thing to do is a Samsung 11.6" Series 9 convertible. Of course many are insisting that the price point is about $500. But doesn't a really good computer cost more like $1000 ? Now Samsung has some popular detachable tablets. The ATIV 500T, at $750, is for longer battery life while the ATIV 700T, at $1200, is for higher performance.But both will run Photoshop. Of course these detachable tablets are low in weight when detached from the keyboard. HP has a Elite Pad 900 tablet scheduled for January while Lenovo has a Thinkpad 2 tablet not yet available.
